content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It was fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: According to the result of the discussion.

Now I solved the problem in a language without "eval, exec ..." support.
I have an idea how to avoid binary output. You can output a sequence of operations from left to right to calculate the value 24, for example: "++-", "-+-", "none".

Binary output should be avoided for clashes based on contribution guidelines. Currently there are only two possible outputs (YES/NO), so the clash suffers from a binary output issue. Please change the output requirement.

Also, it's better to use loopline than string in the stub generator for the current clash.

Thanks.

Oh thanks for pointing out having to avoid binary output. I've changed the output requirement to three options.

Also, implemented loopline.

Thanks for thinking along! I was a bit lazy with writing the solution and eval/exec was the first thing coming to my mind, but I like the fact that multiple approaches are possible.

The sequence of operations I find difficult to implement, because there might be multiple solutions (for example 24 6 6 0, for which +--, -+- and some others are possible). So, then I should either include 'there is always only one solution' and pay attention to the cases (which I don't like), or I should include some rules as to ordering the output of multiple solutions (which I also do not like because I prefer to keep the number of rules low). Also, it then should be additionally stated that the order of the four numbers should remain the same.

Instead, I've now chosen to keep it very similar to the original intent (either it is possible or not possible), but I have split the possible situations in two: with only addition, or with some combination of addition and/or subtraction.

While answering you, I realized there is the option of only subtraction (e.g. 27, 1, 1, 1), and I realized that my previous code assumed the numbers to be always in the same order (1,27,1,1 in my previous code came out as not possible). So, I've added a case in which order matters (1,27,1,1 should be reordered to 27-1-1-1 to make it work) - or, you can of course just include a fourth operator at the front (-1+27-1-1 also works). And I have the feeling there might be other solutions altogether, one of which you might have.
Thanks for the extended answer! But I'm not sure that the rules allow putting a minus before the first number (-1+27-1-1). I suggest waiting for the opinions of other reviewers on this matter.

Do you mean the rules of the 24-game? I think for the 24-game, you are at least allowed to reshuffle the numbers in any order you want. As for implementing that in code, reshuffling the numbers is pretty much the same as including a minus sign before the first number without reshuffling (i.e.: -1+27-1-1 in code is a lazy solution for the situation in which reordering to (+)27-1-1-1 is required).
